title: RL33119
content: Federal highway, highway safety, and transit programs are subject to periodic reauthorization. The most recent authorization before SAFETEA was the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA-21), which provided funds for FY1998-FY2003. Short-term extensions created uncertainty in funding, leading to the consensus that long-term reauthorizations, like TEA-21, are better for planning highway and transit infrastructure. SAFETEA was welcomed by the transportation community, despite delays, as it provided funding until FY2009. Federal funding for surface transportation is closely linked to the revenue stream provided by the highway trust fund, which consists of separate accounts for highways and mass transit. The primary revenue sources are gasoline and diesel fuel taxes, with fuel taxes providing about 90% of the income. The trust fund has seen several tax increases over its almost 50-year lifespan, with the last increase in 1993. In FY2004, the highway account received $31 billion in tax revenues, while the mass transit account received $5 billion. The trust funds have historically collected more tax revenues than expended, but this trend is changing. In FY2004, the highway account received $31 billion in tax revenues, while the mass transit account received $5 billion. Despite a substantial unexpended balance, there is uncertainty about the trust fund's long-term financial health. The American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 provided additional future income by changing federal gasohol taxation, potentially adding $4 billion per year starting in FY2005. Reauthorization legislation was passed by both the House and Senate in the 2nd Session of the 108th Congress. The Conference Committee in the 2nd Session of the 108th Congress could not agree on total program funding for the next reauthorization period. Some Members of Congress wanted more project funding than the Bush Administration supported, due to concerns about the trust funds' future health and opposition to raising fuel taxes. Various mechanisms, including gasohol changes and tax adjustments, were proposed to increase program funding. Conferees considered several revenue-increasing provisions, some of which were included in the finance title of the act. The finance title of the act includes provisions for modest revenue increases, mainly from cutting tax fraud and transferring Treasury general fund revenues to the trust fund. It was believed that these changes, combined with gasohol legislation and expected economic growth, would be enough to finance the $286.4 billion program. TEA-21 altered the highway trust fund's relationship to the Federal Unified Budget by creating new budget categories and setting limitations on obligations. It also introduced Revenue Aligned Budget Authority (RABA) to adjust funding amounts. The Revenue Aligned Budget Authority (RABA) was introduced in TEA-21 to adjust funding amounts in the highway account based on generated revenues. This set predetermined levels of funding for core highway and transit programs, creating "firewalls" to prevent funds from being used for other purposes. Additional funds could be allocated through the annual appropriations process, but this rarely occurred except in FY2003. SAFETEA has maintained these provisions. SAFETEA has largely retained the budget format introduced in TEA-21, with most of the debate revolving around money distribution. It provides a significant increase in funding, with $286.4 billion guaranteed for FY2004-FY2009 compared to $218 billion in TEA-21 for FY1998-2003. SAFETEA represents a boost for federal surface transportation programs, though not as much as originally hoped for. It offers over $244 billion in guaranteed spending authority for FY2005-FY2009, benefiting all major programs affected by the legislation. The legislation receives significant new funding, with total annual spending increases each year. Funding details for major programs can be found in the report's appendix. The House version of SAFETEA included a provision for Congress to reconsider funding at a later date, which was opposed by the Bush Administration. TEA-21 created a spending mechanism to adjust highway program obligations based on trust fund revenue changes. RABA provided significant funding in its first three years. The RABA computation in FY2003 called for a program reduction, but Congress chose to increase spending instead. This led to a push to change how RABA was calculated to reduce revenue swings. SAFETEA changed the calculation to a two-year basis and delayed it until FY2007, with spending reductions only if the highway trust fund balance falls below $6 billion. Transportation policy battles often align regionally rather than along party lines, especially regarding the distribution of federal highway aid among states. Some states have complained about receiving less federal highway aid than they contribute in taxes, pushing for a higher share rate-of-return, while other states oppose any reduction in their existing shares. Donor states argue for equity, stating they have been subsidizing the repair of infrastructure in donee states for too long. They also argue they are more road dependent and do not benefit from federal transit spending as much as some donee states. Southern and western donor states argue that their fast growth areas have needs as great or greater than donee states, and that the completion of the Interstate Highway System eliminates the rationale for the donor-donee disparity. Donee state advocates emphasize the age of their infrastructure, high costs of working on congested urban roads, and limited financial resources in large western states to justify their donee status. They also argue for federal funding based on national needs rather than state boundaries, criticizing Midwestern and southern states for spending less on highways and pleading for federal funds without contributing their own resources. The debate over equity remedies has broader implications for overarching issues. The debate over equity remedies in transportation funding has implications for federal-state roles and funding allocation. Issues include the impact of a 95% rate of return guarantee on addressing other transportation needs, the potential shift towards a revenue sharing or block grant program, and the inclusion of Federal Transit Administration programs in the Minimum Guarantee. The 109th Congress faced challenges in balancing donor and donee state demands with limited Highway Trust Fund revenue. The previous debate over equity remedies in transportation funding had implications for federal-state roles and funding allocation. The 109th Congress faced challenges in balancing donor and donee state demands with limited Highway Trust Fund revenue. To overcome obstacles, previous reauthorization bills included "hold harmless" provisions to maintain base shares for all states. This required increasing the federal highway program size significantly to bring donor state shares up to a designated percentage. Providing equity remedies in this way was costly, resulting in the largest highway program under TEA21. Ultimately, SAFETEA replaced the previous program with a modest and gradual increase in the guaranteed rate-of-return to the states. SAFETEA replaces the TEA-21 MG program with an "Equity Bonus" program, ensuring states receive a guaranteed rate-of-return of 90.5% for FY2005-2006, 91.5% for FY2007, and 92% for FY2008-2009. The act includes various programs subject to the equity provision and introduces new formula programs. Hold harmless provisions are also included in the EB program. The EB program includes hold harmless provisions for certain states based on criteria such as population density, income, fatality rate on highways, and fuel tax rate. Twenty-seven states qualify under these criteria. The Equity Bonus Program guarantees that no state may receive less than a set percentage of its average annual TEA-21 apportionments. Annual percentage floors are set for each fiscal year. The programmatic distribution of funds prioritizes certain programs and distributes any excess funds based on program apportionments. Over the five-year SAFETEA life, the EB program distributions will cost $40.9 billion. (CRS contacts: Robert Kirk and John Fischer) SAFETEA apportions funds to states annually for various programs, known as "apportioned" or formula programs. Under TEA-21, most highway funding was allocated to five core programs, which SAFETEA increased to six: IM, NHS, STP, HBRR, CMAQ, and HSIP. The EB program, replacing the TEA-21 minimum guarantee, is also considered a core program. The majority of funding in the surface transportation bill goes to these core highway programs. SAFETEA includes additional apportioned programs like metropolitan planning and recreational trails. It introduces two new formula programs: Coordinated Border Infrastructure Program (CBI) and Safe Routes to School Program (SRSP). Funding distribution is based on various factors such as lane miles, vehicle miles traveled, and state share of total cost for deficient bridges or non-attainment area population under the Clean Air Act. SAFETEA made adjustments to existing program formulas, including eliminating the 10% safety STP set-aside and creating a $20 million NHS set-aside for ferry construction. It also adjusted the calculation for weighted non-attainment areas under CMAQ and set new funding levels for the Territorial Highway Program and off-system bridge program. The formula distribution is based on federal lane miles and total lane miles of federal-aid highways in each state. The SAFETEA act made adjustments to existing program formulas, including changes to the Railway-Highway Crossings program funding distribution. It also required states to set aside $90 million annually for high-risk rural road improvements from HSIP funds. Under TEA-21, this was a discretionary program, but SAFETEA made it mandatory. Under SAFETEA, funds are apportioned to states along the Canada-U.S. and Mexico-U.S. borders based on specific formulas. This includes allocations for commercial truck crossings, personal vehicle and bus crossings, incoming cargo weight, and the number of ports-of-entry. States receive apportionments based on student enrollment in primary and middle schools, with a minimum of $1 million per state. Highway programs not apportioned are subject to allocations based on criteria in highway authorization and appropriation law. The allocated programs in SAFETEA are based on criteria in highway laws and may be subject to congressional earmarking. These programs include high priority projects, federal lands program, interstate maintenance discretionary program, bridge discretionary program, and transportation and community system pilot preservation program. SAFETEA also introduces new programs like transportation improvement program, national corridor infrastructure program, and projects of national or regional significance, all subject to 100% earmarking. The Appalachian Development Highway Program (ADHP) aims to break regional isolation and promote economic development in Appalachia, funded through the highway trust fund. The Appalachian Development Highway Program (ADHP) is funded through the highway trust fund and aims to break regional isolation and promote economic development in Appalachia. Funds are apportioned to member states based on their "cost to complete" estimates of the approved Appalachian Development Highway System (ADHS). The program received $450 million in contract authority annually under TEA-21 and $470 million annually under SAFETEA. The Transportation Enhancement (TE) program funds various project categories such as scenic beautification, historic preservation, rehabilitation of historic transportation buildings, and environmental mitigation. Funding for TE activities is now set at 10% of funds apportioned to a state under the Surface Transportation Program (STP) or the amount apportioned in FY2005, ensuring additional funding for enhancement projects. The Transportation, Community, and System Preservation (TCSP) program assists in planning and implementing strategies for transportation integration. The TCSP program, authorized under SAFETEA, aims to integrate transportation, community, and system preservation plans. It provides funding for projects to improve transportation efficiency, reduce environmental impacts, and encourage compatible private sector development patterns. Eligible entities include state, tribal, regional, and local governments. The program has a six-year total funding authorization of $270 million, with varying amounts authorized for different fiscal years. Under TEA-21, TCSP funding was authorized at $20 million for FY1999 and $25 million per year for FY2000 through FY2003. The Safe Routes to School Program, funded at $612 million for FY2004-FY2009, encourages children to walk and bike to school, promoting a healthy lifestyle from an early age. The Safe Routes to School Program allocates funds to states based on student enrollment ratios, with a minimum of $1 million per state per year. The federal share of project costs is 100%, and funds are available until expended. Eligible agencies include state, local, and regional entities, as well as nonprofit organizations. Funds can be used for infrastructure projects to improve walking and biking to school. The Safe Routes to School Program funds infrastructure projects to improve walking and biking to school, including sidewalk improvements, traffic calming measures, bicycle facilities, pedestrian crossing improvements, and secure bike parking. States can also use funds for non-infrastructure activities like public awareness campaigns, traffic education, and coordinator positions for safe routes to school programs. Additionally, SAFETEA guarantees $45.3 billion in transit funding for the five-year authorization period, with a 46% increase over the previous funding levels. The share of transit funding for Urbanized Area Formula Program decreased from 47.9% to 44.0%, while the Non-Urbanized Formula Program increased from 3.3% to 5.2%. Funding distribution among states shifted, with larger states receiving less and smaller states receiving more. The federal transit program structure saw minor changes, including new programs, funding categories, and modifications to existing programs. Additional provisions included offering transit passes as a fringe benefit and earmarks for the Bus and Bus Facilities Program. The program is intended to be administered as a new program, not a continuation of any previous program. The act also reauthorizes the Swift Rail Act, expanding eligible expenses from "planning" to "development" of high-speed rail. The Swift Rail Act authorizes funding for high-speed rail corridor development and technology improvements. It also allocates funds for the elimination of rail-highway grade crossing hazards and grants for the Alaska Railroad. Additionally, the act requires the Federal Railroad Administration to establish a program for rail joint bar inspection data review. SAFETEA authorizes the Highway Safety Improvement Program, which replaces the roadway hazard elimination program and focuses on installing barriers and guard rails. The Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP) authorizes funding for hazard elimination, with $1.2 billion in FY2006 rising to $1.3 billion by FY2009. Funding is apportioned based on lane-miles, vehicle miles traveled, and fatalities on federal-aid highways. $220 million annually is reserved for rail-highway grade crossing hazard elimination, and $90 million for high-risk rural roads projects. States must spend at least $317 million annually on hazard elimination, with the remainder available for other highway projects if not needed for safety improvements. The Safe Routes to Schools program allocates funds for infrastructure projects near schools to enhance children's safety while walking or biking. States can redirect funds from safety projects on grade crossings or high-risk rural roads if safety needs are met. Additionally, a grant program is established to promote seat belt use, with funding increasing from $54 million in FY2005 to $183 million in FY2009. The program authorizes grants for states with primary seat belt laws or high seat belt use rates. Grants can be used for highway safety purposes with 100% federal funding. The program also expands grants to reduce alcohol-impaired driving rates, requiring states to implement specific programs to qualify for funding. The program authorizes grants for states to implement various measures to reduce alcohol-impaired driving rates, including saturation patrols, increased blood alcohol testing, harsher penalties for high BAC levels, rehabilitation programs, prevention strategies for underage drinking, and funding for community programs. Grants can also be used for administrative license revocation systems and returning fines to communities. The total authorization for the program is $555 million over the authorization period. Activities in research and technology development play a crucial role in addressing challenges faced by the nation's surface transportation systems, such as congestion, security, and environmental degradation. The federal government, through agencies like FHWA, FTA, NHTSA, and RITA, aims to advance the use of safer technologies and infrastructure to mitigate these challenges. FHWA administers a significant research and technology development program, with an annual budget of approximately $295 million authorized by Title V of SAFETEA. SAFETEA authorizes significant funding for transportation research and education, including $169.4 million for surface transportation research, $26.7 million for training and education, $27 million for the Bureau of Transportation Statistics, and $69.7 million for the University Transportation Research Program. Research funds are used to improve highway infrastructure and safety, with state and industry experts emphasizing the importance of these funds for maximizing the effective use of federal aid. Title IX of SAFETEA, "Rail Transportation," focuses on infrastructure capacity, rail-to-rail competition, and grade crossing conflicts in freight rail transportation. Congress is considering assisting freight railroads in expanding their infrastructure to handle increasing trade volumes and alleviate highway congestion. Another issue is the impact of more frequent freight train traffic on towns and neighborhoods, leading to delays at grade crossings. Despite reducing railway miles, railroads are intensifying track usage for operational efficiency. Congressional discussions on assisting railroads have been ongoing since the industry's price deregulation in 1980. The captive shipper question has been a congressional issue since rail industry deregulation in 1980. Concerns include high rail rates and poor service for shippers served by only one railroad. SAFETEA addresses these issues in title IX, with a request for a report on rail system performance and funding mechanisms for track rehabilitation. The RRIF Program under SAFETEA expands to $35 billion in total value of available loans, with $7 billion reserved for smaller railroads. Loans must be provided within 90 days without requiring collateral. Loans can be issued for constructing rail connections and enhancing rail infrastructure capacity. The SAFETEA program includes funding for enhancing rail infrastructure capacity, relocating rail tracks, and eliminating grade crossings in various regions across the United States. This program authorizes grants totaling $350 million annually from 2006 to 2009, with specific allocations for projects of national and regional significance such as improving rail connections in Virginia, planning a freight rail tunnel in New York, and eliminating grade crossings in Chicago and Los Angeles. The SAFETEA program allocates funding for rail infrastructure projects across the United States, including relocating rail yards in El Paso and a rail line connection in Portsmouth. It also mandates a comprehensive study of the nation's rail transportation system since deregulation in 1980. Additionally, a new grant program called the Freight Intermodal Distribution Pilot Grant Program is established to improve freight mobility around U.S. ports. The SAFETEA program continues the Recreational Trails Program (RTP) to help states develop and maintain recreational trails for various trail uses. It authorizes $370 million in contract authority for FY2005-2009 and sets aside $840,000 annually for administrative expenses. Funds are allocated to states by a legislative formula. Under SAFETEA, the Recreational Trails Program (RTP) allocates funds to states based on off-road recreational fuel use. States must use 30% of RTP funds for motorized trails, 30% for non-motorized trails, and 40% for diverse trail uses. SAFETEA eliminates waivers for the 30% provision but retains exemptions for small states. The program also adjusts the federal share for RTP projects and encourages states to use youth conservation or service corps for trail construction and maintenance. SAFETEA expands permissible uses for RTP funding to include trail safety, monitoring patrols, and training. It also allows funding for trail condition assessment and permits pre-approval planning and environmental compliance costs to be credited toward project costs. The Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991 (ISTEA) established the Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality Improvement (CMAQ) program to reduce emissions from highway travel and help states comply with air quality standards. As of May 2005, 124 areas with a population of 159 million must develop State Implementation Plans (SIPs) to reach attainment under the Clean Air Act. Federal agencies are prohibited from funding projects in these areas unless they conform to the SIPs, ensuring they do not worsen air quality or delay standard attainment. Transportation Improvement Programs (TIPs) must demonstrate conformity every two years to receive federal funds for highway and transit projects. The impact of conformity requirements is expected to increase due to emissions from SUVs and light trucks. The growth of emissions from SUVs and light trucks, along with increased vehicle miles traveled, has made it difficult to demonstrate conformity.
